reviewText: What a setting for a live concert, the steps of the Sydney opera house with 120,000 lively fans in attendance.  As others have said, the musical performance is stunning.  Compliments must also go to everyone involved in the production - the sound is to die for, the cameras give every performer his due in sharp focus, the staging and colors are eye-candy.  This is one of those things that gets better with each viewing.  One of the best performance videos I've seen.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Of all of the musical concert purchases I have ever made at Amazon whether instant or through pre-order, this is without question the one I looked forward to the most once the order had been placed. I could not believe that this concert was made available and never expected to hear them again. When I first read about CH in 1999...yep, I missed them as they flew, I had no idea who they were.  I had read an online review here, (thank you, whoever you are) took a chance, and I have never regretted it. Forunately, those of us latecomers were able to see and hear Neil and Tim together and alone over the years.And now to hear that the band is reforming, albeit without their beloved drummer, well, all I can say is despite all the sh#* that goes down in this world, it is a good time to be alive to hear this band make their magic once more.Meets and exceeds all expectations of a live concert DVD. Let's make it # 1 and keep it there for awhile and allow Neil's band to receive the credit they richly deserve.
Title: N/A

reviewerName: John S. Harris "The Voice of Reason"
reviewText: Great DVD.  Good camera work from the live show.  Excellent stage show.  The bonus features on disc two very likely could have fit onto Disc One with the concert, but there's something about a multi-disc set that makes a DVD release seem like it has "value-added" properties.Generally happy with the set list, though I wish "That's What I Call Love" was on there.  I saw the band in a club in Memphis in 1986 and recorded a live concert of theirs off the radio about the same time.  Both shows featured "TWICL" and they were rockin' and a real highlight.Oh well  -- at least I got to meet the band after the show and get my cassette of their first album autographed.  Wonder if I still have that.Good DVD and good value for the money.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The band Crowded House formed from the break-up of the quirky brilliant New Zealand pop band Split Enz.  Founded by Tim Finn Split Enz was often a bit too obtuse for their own good, but it built a fan base that was passionate as a result.  When Tim's brother Neil joined the band had already matured into a much more accessible outfit and Neil completed that transformation as witnessed by the pop gem "I've Got You".  Neil was just getting started and Crowded House took Neil's melodic pop mastery further.  Strangley in America Crowded House peaked sales wise with their first self title album.  Curious thing that measurement of success by units moved.  While Crowded House was a light and dark pop masterpiece all the albums that followed were equally wonderful. The world outside the U.S. continued to agree as world-wide success followed.  A fantastic, often deeply moving and fun, song catalog followed.  Crowded House was a the perfect platform for the wonderkind often times referred to as "The Down-Under McCartney".Most bands have a life-span dictated by various sometimes mundane, other times more complicated, reasons.  I won't venture to guess everything that played into the retirement of Crowded House, but will say they went out still loving one another and very much on top.  Their final farewell concert was a true gift to fans.  It was staged in a spectacular fashion in the Sydney Harbor adjacent the iconic Sydney Opera House.  It was a huge event nationally televised and filmed for video.  One problem was if you didn't live in Australia, or Europe for that matter, and you blinked you missed your opportunity to own the concert first released on VHS PAL-Format tape.  Perhaps a limited run or something more obscure, but it never got a lot of traction on bootlegs.  Fans such as myself were heart broken as we'd read about how glorious it was, and later could listen as proof when if was available on a CD version in America.  Thankfully circa 2007 that changed and a wonderful thing happened:  you could buy a NTSC deluxe 2-DVD version of Farewell to the World.  Thanks Amazon for making this available as I still couldn't find it locally.  It has been a purchase I have cherished ever since.  The production is spectacular and it is full 16:9 widescreen glory and wonderful 5.1 sound.I've collected everything concert wise I could possibly find with Neil and Crowded House up to fairly recent concerts (2012) and I must say this is by far the best and that's saying a lot since they're all gems.  This show lives up to everything one could wish for.  There's poignancy in spades as a last concert would naturally embue, but there's more.  There's the priceless look into Paul Hester's humor as witnessed by his stage banter between Neil and the audience.  I am guessing Paul suffered for bipolar disorder having breath taking highs and bone-crushing lows.  It's fantastic witnessing the guy so many loved in fine form here artistically and personally.  If Neil was the heart of Crowded House, Paul was the lungs that breathed spontanuity and life into the aggregate of Neil and Nick.  It just couldn't be more open for your inspection, and joyous awe, as presented here.  Yes, this is a pop concert for the ages.  Kind of like seeing The Beatles with all of the members present...Even Tim Finn shows up putting it over the top.If you can find this concert and you love top-shelf pop music it's an absolute must to beg, borrow, or steal to get it.  It's that good.  The music crushes and the guys play their hearts out for a huge mass of loving fans.  Concert DVDs rarely reach these heights.  I love this band, I love this DVD...Thank you Crowded House for all of the other worldly musical pleasure you've given me.  I'm so glad in spite of tragedy these guys didn't call it a day as they still strike a rare cord of emotional pop that moves me today.  Still, it simply doesn't get better than this concert here.  Find it, get it, cherish it too.
summary: The Greatest Underated Successful Band Gives One Of The Greatest Concerts Ever
Title: N/A

reviewText: Recorded in 1996 at the Sydney Opera House plaza, "Crowded House" plays their farewell concert to an appreciative crowd of over 120,000.  The 24-song set contains amazingly pure and tight sound with Neil Finn's voice at its best.  There are no stand-out cuts, as the band gives it best performance to date on every track.  It is flawless.  The comments from the band to the audience between songs makes this one of the most personable concerts ever recorded.  Slight variations on some songs and an accent here and there make the fans sing along throughout.  The closing song, "Don't Dream its Over" is as emotional as ever, with shots of the crowd signing along and the band emoting, realizing this really is their last song together.  It's one of the best concerts of the last two decades.The extras include an optional commentary by the band in subtitles.  The second disc has a 20-minute documentary about the enormous planning it took to stage this event, mostly narrated by the band's manager. Also included are a few featurettes, a photo gallery and the full "Crowded House" discography.  This is one of those collectable packages that you'll never tire of.
summary: One Of The Best Live Recordings Ever!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is the first DVD recording of Crowded House's last concert - their final show from the steps of the Sydney Opera House in November 1996 in front of 120 000 people. The band was on fire and they played all the hits. The contents of this DVD is the same as the other edition; the package, however, is the slimline foldout package compared to the typical plastic DVD case of the other.Included on this DVD:* 5 tracks / performances included on the DVD, not on the previous VHS release.* Brand new documentary "The Day They Brought The House Down" including new interviews with Neil Finn and Nick Seymour. Two other documentaries also included; Australian journalist Jana Wendt's "Witness" piece and "Planning The Event".* Photo gallery and Credit roll sections includes three previously unreleased original demos.* Band commentary for the entire concert, with Neil Finn & Nick Seymour.* Recut shot-by-shot to 16:9 widescreen.* Re-graded and re-edited concert.* Digitally re-mastered. New stereo mix and new 5.1 DTS mix. Also contains original stereo mix from the VHS.Track listingDisc 1:1. Mean To Me2. World Where You Live3. When You Come4. Private Universe5. Four Seasons In One Day6. Fall At Your Feet7. Whispers And Moans8. Hole In The River9. Better Be Home Soon10. Pineapple Head11. Distant Sun12. Into Temptation13. Everything Is Good For You14. Locked Out15. Something So Strong16. Sister Madly17. Italian Plastic18. Weather With You19. It's Only Natural20. There Goes God21. Fingers Of Love22. In My Command23. Throw Your Arms Around Me24. Don't Dream It's Over25. End Credits - Farewell To The World ConcertDisc 2:1. Planning The Event - Documentary2. The Day They Brought The House Down Documentary3. 'witness' - Documentary4. Italian Plastic (Photo Gallery Plus Audio)5. Instinct (Photo Gallery Plus Audio)6. End Credits - Farewell To The World DVDPaul Hester's performance is haunting. I recently read an interview with Neil Finn (who is currently collaborating with Nick Seymour for a 2007 release!) and he recalls the night vividly despite not having watched the footage since. Of Hester, Finn says that sadness was written all over Hester's face, especially as they concert neared its conclusion. It is bittersweet to watch him. On Crowded House's performance, Finn claims he witnesses a band at the height of their powers - enough said! This DVD is a necessary addition for any Crowded House fan or any fan who wants to own a memorable concert.

reviewText: The 3 Documentaries include REALLY good rehearsal footage, TV interviews and BEHIND THE SCENES stuff that REALLY make the DVD worthwhile!  I saw CROWDED HOUSE every time they came through CHICAGO and they are in my top 5 favorite bands of all time.  This DVD doesn't disappoint and now CROWDED HOUSE are reforming!  Neil and Nick are looking for a new DRUMMER in their hometown and LA...so we may be treated to some more concerts VERY soon!  Ironically, another favorite band is reuniting...THE POLICE and opening the GRAMMY AWARDS in 2007!

reviewText: This is a brilliant DVD.It showcases what a GREAT band Crowded House was. What a greatsongwriter Neil Finn is and what a incredible drummer Paul Hester was.The audio commentary by Neil, Nick Seymour and Mark Hart add a wonderfultouch to what was already a emotional event. They laugh and kid one another, pointing out miscues and mistakes made that night. They speak warmly and fondly about the late Paul Hester.The concert captured here looks and sounds fantastic.This DVD of their final concert is, for me the missing link in my Crowded House puzzle. Crowded House became, and still is my 2nd favorite band behind The Beatles.I still have the '45 of "Don't Dream It's Over" which began my love affair with this band. 4 studio albums later, plus, a greatest hits and a rarities CD, plus the solo Finn and Finn's CD's and the great DVD collection of their video clips (along with my Together Alone t-shirt)I found that I was missing one thing: I never saw the band live.Now I have.Brilliant.I look forward with much anicipation the new Crowded House album and tour.Be home soon, boys.
summary: What Crowded House Means To Me

reviewText: I confess I had not heard of this DVD until recently. It has great sound, great music and commemorates how good Crowded House was as a live band. Of course Neil Finn's writing is at the core of this music; and this presentation is both strong and light hearted even as it brims with emotion.

reviewText: I gotta tell you first that I'm a longtime fan of crowded house. I couldn't get enough of Paul Hester, Neil Finn and Nick Seymour when they first conquered the world. Yes, that they did! The brilliant songwriting of the three men, but especially Neil made this band a truly unique and special one. They conquered the international airwaves with their beautiful, deep songs. So, it was truly fitting that they would do a farewell concert after Paul Hester had decided to leave the band and hang out at home to watch his daughters grow up. Sadly, Paul left this world a few years ago when he took his own life. It is a shame we lost such an incredible talent. Still, this video is a loving tribute to an extraordinary band with that "something special". This is a great, not good, concert. We only see a touch of Paul's comedic side but it's the songs and the camera work that make this a superb concert. Shot in 1996 it is also in letterbox. Most concert videos made at that time in the states were pan and scan so kudos to Australia for giving us a remarkable concert with a concert view. Nothing is cut off from this "theatrical" concert. You get to see Neil, Nick, Paul, Mark, who would eventually become a regular member of Crowded House after Paul left, and Tim Finn, who joins for a few songs later in the concert. So, if you're new to crowded house or an old time fan this concert belongs in your collection. The band still rocks to this day but I believe the great stuff was made during the ten years of 1986 to 1996. If you want a place to start then order Farewell to the World Live on dvd and CD, their self-titled first album, Crowded House, Woodface, The Temple of Low Men, and Together Alone and you'll be completely immersed in the brilliance that is Crowded House.
Title: N/A

reviewText: As fans know, Crowded House was a tremendous live band.  Each show I saw was always unique and great fun. The DVD version of the last CH concert only confirms the memories.  What a great way to end (and kick start) a great band.  The Farewell show is amazing for its song selection, so many great CH classics, the adoring crowd and most of all, to celebrate the talents of the band.  The concert is filmed with no gimmicks.  Just the band playing and the usual fun interplay between songs, obviously a little more somber on this occasion. Listening to the 5.1 sound is terrific: you get the full, clear sound of the instruments and to appreciate the wonderful vocal harmonies and counter-play of their voices.  The full sound of the band, Neil's guitar, Paul Hester's talent as a drummer, Nick Seymour's ever bouncing bass and Mark Hart's multi instruments, never sounded better.  They are tight and sound great. Tim Finn also appears on great versions of "Weather with You" and "It's Only Natural". Disc One is the full show, in all of its glory.  Disc Two has three documentary/ newscasts about the show, which are not to be missed.  There are also two unreleased versions of "Instinct" and Paul Hester penned "Italian Plastic".As sad an occasion as this last show (for the moment) was, as Neil says in one of the interviews on Disc Two, it was a celebration of a great band.  Now, with all of the rumors of the reunion, new album and tour, get ready world, for the rebirth.  Farewell to the World will stand as a testament to the greatness of CH, Neil Finn's brilliant songs and the collective talents of the band.  Paul surely will be missed and always remembered yet it appears that the time is ripe for more.  While we gear up for what is upcoming, get this one now. This is one of the greatest concert DVDs and extras that you will find.
summary: 10 Years on and More To Come!!!
